Ibid. p.49. Such impressions were later echoed and elaborated in a novel, see Yitzhak Dov Berkowitz,Yemot ha-mashi'ah[Days of the Messiah] (Tel Aviv: Dvir, 1938), p.167.
Gibbons, John. 1936.The Road to Nazareth81London: R. Hale.

For instance, see Pieter M. Judson, ‘Frontiers, Islands, Forests, Stones: Mapping the Geography of German Identity in the Habsburg Monarchy, 1848–1900’, inThe Geography of identity, ed. by Patricia Yaeger (Ann Arbor: University of Michigan Press, 1999), pp.382–406 (pp.399–400). Also see Maoz Azaryahu, ‘German Reunification and the Politics of Street Names: The Case of East Berlin’,Political Geography, 16.6 (1997), 479–93. Paulina Raento and Cameron J. Watson, ‘Gernika, Guernica,Guernica?Contested Meanings of a Basque Place’,Political Geography, 19.6 (2000), 707–36. Also see Naftali Kadmon,Toponymy: The Lore, Lavs and Language of Geographical Names(New York: Vantage Press, 2000), pp.194–6.

Yehuda Ziv, ‘Shmotav holkhim lefanav’ [His Names Go before Him],Leshonenu la-am[Our Language for the People], 50.1 (1999), 39–47. Yossi Katz, “Va'adat ha-shemot shel ha-kakal u-kevi'at shemot ha-yishuvim bi-tekufat ha-mandat' [The JNF Name Committee and Determining Settlements' Names in the Mandatory Era],Iyunim Bitekumat Israel, 9 (1999), 280–315.

Yossi Katz, ‘Shemot mekomot ve-tafkidam ha-politi’ [Place Names and their Political Function],Mehkarim be-geograjyah shel eretzyisrael[Researches in The Land of Israel's Geography], 15 (1998), 105–16 (p.106).

For instance see I. D. Bar—Drora,Mi-mo'azab mekomit le-iriyah[From Township to Municipality] (Petah Tikvah: Petah Tikvah Municipality, 1938), p.28. Hayim Aharonowitz,Hadar ha-Carmel(Haifa: Hadar ha-Carmel Committee, 1958), p.148. Yossi Ben—Artzi, ‘Shemot shel rehovot ve-toldot ir’ [Street Names and a City's History],Jewish Language Review, 7 (1987), xvi-xxv. And compare with diasporic patterns—see Yitzchak Ganuz,‘Shemot rehovot be-ayarot russyah ha-levanha[Street Names in Belarus Towns],Yeda Am, 17.41–12 (1975), 69–71. Also see Eli Lederhendler, ‘New York City, The Jews, and “the Urban Experience‘“, inPeople of the City: Jews and the Urban Challenge: Studies in Contemporary Jewry, XV, ed. by Ezra Mendelsohn (New York and Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999), pp.49–67 (p.51).

Street naming has a primary practical facet but in Tel Aviv its symbolic element was prominent from the very start: whereas houses were methodically numbered only in the 1930s, street names were carefully discussed and chosen as early as the 1910s, when the neighbourhood numbered only six streets—Yedi'ot iriyat Tel Aviv, sefer hashana Tanzat, [Tel Aviv Municipality's Bulletin, 1938–1939 Yearbook] pp.73–4. Letter from Deputy Mayor Rokach to local newspapers, October 1934, Tel Aviv Jaffa Municipality Historical Archive (hereafter TAA), 4/2641. Ben-Yishai (see note 1), p.38.

Born in Bessarabia in 1861, Meir Dizengoff was a Zionist activist and businessman and one of Tel Aviv's founders. He headed the neighbourhood's committee and when Tel Aviv became a township he served as mayor (with the exception of 1926–28) until his death in 1936.

Ben-Yishai (see note 1), pp.37–2. Letter from Dizengoff to the cultural committee, June 1925, TAA, 3/75a. Letters from Dizengoff and other council members to the street-naming committee, 1929–34, TAA, 4/2623. Letter from Dizengoff to Hebrew writers and scholars, January 1934, Beit Bialik Archive, D54. Suggested names by street-naming committee, December 1933, TAA, 4/2623c. Bar—Gal, ‘Shemot’ (see note 8), p.127.
Letter from the deputy mayor, October 1934, TAA, 4/2641.Yedi'ot iriyat Tel Aviv(see note 22), pp.73–4.
For instance Ben-Yishai (see note 1), p.38.
Letter from the municipality to Balfour, October 1922, TAA, 2/50a (and a translation of his reply, TAA, 2/83a).
Letters from Ben-Yishai to Rokach, May and August 1935, TAA, 4/2624b. Sokolow, an honorary citizen of Tel Aviv, was the person who suggested Tel Aviv' as the young neighbourhood's name in 1910.
Municipal correspondence, February-March 1934, TAA, 4/2623c.

Letter from Dizengoff to the Brussels Zionist Association, February 1934, TAA, 4/2623c. Letter from Hefftman to Dizengoff, December 1934, TAA, 4/2624a. Internal municipal correspondence from December 1934, TAA, 4/2624a. For other political considerations in street—naming, see a letter from the Jewish Agency in Jerusalem, February 1936, TAA, 4/2624b, and internal municipal correspondence from August 1936, TAA, 4/2624b.

Letters from December 1938, TAA, 4/2624d. The writers claimed that Samuel supports ‘the Palestinian Hitler, the Mufti’, Hajj Amin al-Husseini. It was Samuel who appointed al-Husseini as Mufti (expounder of Muslim law) of Jerusalem in an attempt to appease the Arabs in 1922, but in 1937, after taking an active leading part in the Arab Revolt, the latter was dismissed and escaped to continue activity in exile.

Letter from the council of non-political organisations, November 1938, TAA, 4/2624d. Correspondence between the municipality and ‘Young Israel’, January-February 1939, TAA, 4/2624d. The municipality did not erase Samuel's name nor did it name a street after Roosevelt.

Letter concerning the plight of Russian Jewry, 1921, TAA, 2/39a. Letter from Dizengoff to the German Consul, 1933, TAA, 4/3220. Municipal correspondence from 1938–1939, TAA, 4/4161. And see Gideon Shimoni, ‘Behinah me-hadash shel “shelilat ha-galut” ke-ra'ayon u-ma'aseh’ (Reconsidering “The Negation of Diaspora” as Idea and Practice], inIdan ha-zvyonut[The Era of Zionism], ed. by Anita Shapira, Jehuda Reinharz and Jay Harris (Jerusalem: Merkaz Zalman Shazar, 2000), pp.45–52.
On political objections to commemorative names see Azaryahu (note 4), p.315. Letter to the municipality, August 1936, TAA, 4/2624b.

On civil society's less ideal facets see Bjoren Beckman, ‘Explaining Democratization: Notes on the Concept of Civil Society’, inCivil Society, Democracy and the Muslim World, ed. by Elizabeth Ozdalga and Sune Persson (Istanbul: Swedish Research Institute in Istanbul, 1997), pp.1–7 (pp.1–5). Nancy Bermeo, ‘Civil Society After Democracy: Some Conclusions’, inCivil Society Before Democracy: Lessons from Nineteenth-Century Europe, ed. by Nancy Bermeo and Philip Nord (Lanham, MD and Oxford: Rowman & LitdeBeld, 2000), pp.237–60 (p.238). Omar G. Encarnacin,The Myth of Civil Society: Social Capital and Democratic Consolidation in Spain and Brazil(New York: Palgrave Macmillan, 2003), pp.6, 9, 170.

1934.Davar, 6 September Examples of Dizengoff representing and personifying Tel Aviv include a caricature in, A child's essay from 1935, TAA, 7(6)/llb. The Purim Celebration Committee,Moreh derekh le-haggotpurim ve-ha'adloyada[Guide to the Purim Celebrations] (Tel Aviv: Hapo'el Haza'ir, 1932), p. ll. The visual centrality of Mugrabi hall can be seen in Soskin's 1930s photograph, Raz (see note 46), p.92. Also see David Shalit,Makrinim Koacb[Projecting Power: The Cinema Houses, the Movies and the Israelis] (Tel Aviv: Resling, 2006), pp.194–9.

Regarding the larger national scale, Bar-Gal claims that street names that are repeated in many towns compose the core of the social consensus, whereas rarer names might indicate belonging to the social margins, Bar—Gal, ‘Hasmalah’ (see note 8), p.119.
Correspondence with D. Z., April-May 1930, TAA, 4/2623a. Correspondence with Y. G. A., August—September, 1933, TAA, 4/2623b.

items.abstract: The spread of workfare to Israel and elsewhere in the world is typically attributed to the power of a globalized neoliberal orthodoxy. This chapter demonstrates how, on the contrary, the introduction of new employment and social policies in Israel bearing the Wisconsin moniker was an attempt to resolve intra-state conflict regarding the goals and instruments of state intervention in the labor market. These conflicts were resolved through by importing new policy ideas. Via translation, it was possible to assemble a change coalition and advance domestic institutional change. Nevertheless, due to the persistence of intra-state conflicts over the goals and instruments of social and labor policies, workfare was implemented alongside existing institutions to create a new institutional layer. Layering was instrumental in overcoming opposition to the program, but also made it vulnerable to politicization. This politicization brought about the interruption of the program five years after its inception.
title: “Wisconsin Works” in Israel? Imported Ideas, Domestic Coalitions, and the Institutional Politics of Recommodification
original-title: “Wisconsin Works” in Israel? Imported Ideas, Domestic Coalitions, and the Institutional Politics of Recommodification
